title.narrative: Fair Finance Asia - Sida - Indonesia Pro

description.narrative:
The Fair Finance Asia Program (FFA) envisages to reduce the negative impact of national and cross-border bank investments in Asia on human rights, the environment and climate change, and to increase adequate financial services for pro-poor, inclusive economic development. The goal is to establish a sustainable financial sector in Asia, with financial sector institutions operating at national and regional level being more transparent and accountable and adhering to Economic, Social and Governance (ESG)-criteria. FFA is funded by Sida.
This project is implemented by Perkumpulan Prakarsa (PRAKARSA). Prakarsa is a local NGO working to nurture and enhancewelfare ideas and initiatives through independent research and active participation for stakeholders in order to create social justice and a prosperous society. It is the lead organisation of the Fair Finance Guide Indonesia (Responsibank) coalition, and was involved in Fair Finance Guide International and Fair Financial Flows programmes.
This project aims to contribute to the FFA goals by developing the capacities of national CSOs that are also participating in the Fair Finance Guide coalition. Capacity development is undertaken to ensure that the high-level regional negotiation, advocacy and lobbyingprocess is performed by CSOs that are well-capacitated on financial sector issues, and are familiar and understand the financial structure in Asia. Research will be performed on 8 existing banks, with a mixture of state-owned banks and (biggest operating)banks in Asia. The research will focus its study on the role of the banks in expanding the palm oil business in Southeast Asia (as the palm oil business is held responsible for deforestation, land degradation, human rights abuse and land grabbing) and investments in cement plant and factories (as they caused social and environmental problems). As part of its influencing efforts, the financial services authority is approached to promote fair finance /sustainable finance in the country and at the regionallevel.
Up until now, Prakarsa as the lead organization play the major role in decision making process. Coalition member organizations are involved mostly in advocacy process with regulators. Some are involvedin the research depends on the focus issueofthe research and the expertise of organization. YLKI as consumer association played important role in financial education, TuK has focused to do campaign in the palm oil financing, WALHI is against fossil fuel financing, Kemitraan is in favor to promote climate finance, PWYP Indonesia has concern on extractive industry but not specific from the investment point of view, while other organizations at the moment do not have specific works that is directly related to financial sector.

participating-org.narrative: Prakarsa Perkumpulan (The Center for Welfare Studies) is a Jakarta-based association, founded in 2004 by a number of civil society activists, who seeks to promote a democratic, just, and prosperous Indonesian society. Perkumpulan Prakarsa works to nurture and enhance welfare ideas and initiatives through independent research, capacity building and active participation for the stakeholders inorder to create social justice and prosperous society. Prakarsa works on a wide range of topics related to welfare issues, with national and local governments, parliaments, CSOs, universities, international organizations, private sector and mass media to bring ideas into initiatives and actions. The 4 focus areas of Prakarsa are welfare policies, fiscal policies, sustainable development; and quantitative and qualitative surveys. Since 2014 Prakarsa leads the Fair Finance Guide Coalition in Indonesia, composed of 7 Indonesia Civil Society organizations. Prakarsa hosted the Annual FFGI meeting in 2016.

description.narrative: Improved policies Governments and global actors: # cases (sub)national governments or global actors adopting and/or implementing improved gender sensitive policies on promotion of a transparent, accountable and inclusive financial sector.
cases (sub)national governments or global actors adopting and/or implementing improved gender sensitive policies on promotion of a transparent, accountable and inclusive financial sector -DD2

comment.narrative:
OJK launched the second phase of the Sustainable Finance roadmap in January 2021. This roadmap became guidance for Financial Institutions (FIs) in implementing sustainable finance.
OJK had established a national task force on Sustainable Finance, specifically in developing green taxonomy, which involves stakeholders from related ministries and institutions.
At the end of 2021, OJK had held a public discussion to announce its draft of green taxonomy. The first version of green taxonomy Indonesia hadbeen released on 20 January 2022.

comment.narrative:
ResponsiBank Indonesia together with FF Netherland, FFA ET and FFI file the complaint letter to ING bank on its financing Coal Fired Power Plant Cirebon unit 2, which against its policy. We urge the ING to immediately stop financing CFPP.
Policy briefentitled “The Fulfillment of Palm Oil Workers’ Rights: One of the Pillars of Sustainable Plantation”. The policy brief provides recommendations to the government particularly the Ministry of Manpower, financiers, investors, buying companies, OJK, and Trade Unions

description.narrative: pieces of evidence (documents, studies, videos, testimonies etc.) produced by Oxfam Novib and partners to support monitoring of practices and implementation of policies by the private sector

comment.narrative: 1 research report on CFPP financing is already finished. Case studies from the previous year about smallholders and labor rights violations in the palm oil sector are already finished. One more case study on the impact of the cement industry is expectingdelay and will be finished in Q1 2022.

comment.narrative: Training on Gender Issues in High-Risk Commodity Sector had delivered by Diana Quiroz, Profundo on 29-30 September 2021. The training was attended by 30 participants from 28 CSOs with the background of researchers and gender activists.

comment.narrative: 1. Join campaign in Adaro Energy debt refinancing, in cooperation with Market forces. 2. Planning joint campaign in phasing out the coal issue, in cooperation with Bersihkan Indonesia coalition. 3. Conducting a case study of labour rights violation in the palm oil sector in West Kalimantan and Central Sulawesi, in cooperation with WALHI. 4. Developing a case study of human rights violations in the cement industry in Kendeng Mountain, Central Java, in cooperation with PWYP Indonesia.
